longtext.content: today we're making a portobello mushroom that's stuffed with cheddar cheese cream cheese bacon and jalapenos so delicious here's how we're gonna make it what i've got here is some beautiful portobello mushrooms they look great nice and large i'm just gonna remove the stems here so easy to remove just gently pull them and they'll come right off so what i'm going to do is just oil them up a little bit oil both sides yeah i'm going to give it a little bit of a season with some salt i'm going to start working on our aromatics i've got some garlic here just give it a smash one more just mince that up beautiful set that to the side so you're gonna also cut up some jalapenos here just remove the stems put down the middle just going to remove those seeds that's where really all the heat lies we're going to do a small dice on these another chop on them we're gonna saute up these jalapenos and garlic so as that begins to cook we're gonna also chop up these beautiful caps of our mushrooms and just coarsely chop it this is gonna get cooked down anyway inside of our pan beautiful same with our stems add your mushrooms to the pan i'm going to give it a season of salt generous season i'm gonna give it a little bit of black pepper just add a little bit more oil mushrooms are like sponges so they really do pick up anything any liquid that you put it with or any oil or fat so that looks good it's cooked down transfer this over to a bowl all right so let's talk about what we've got going on we've got some cream cheese right here we're gonna add the cream cheese in it's softened so that it's pliable we're also going to add in our bacon and our lovely cheddar cheese i'm just gonna give that a mix so look at that really easy we're going to divide this into thirds just kind of eyeball it stack it up really nicely here i'll actually bring this up so you guys can see so this is going to go into an oven 350 degrees preheated and it's going to cook for about 20 minutes we're gonna pull out our mushrooms out of the oven they smell fantastic yes please i'm gonna take this one righ yes please i'm gonna take this one right here give us a little garnish of parsley and we're going to dig in oh yes that just gave me so much life super good really creamy bacon is salty and perfect and i love that the bacon flavor is going all through that mushroom just permeating and perfuming that mushroom so beautifully the cheese is so creamy and it's actually light as much stuff as we got going on inside of here it's not heavy to eat it's so so good guys thanks for watching i'm son of a southern chef and i'll see you next time
longtext.label: all

longtext.content: today I present to you a versatile dish that can be served as a snack as a party food or even as a meal with a salad it's absolutely fantastic and is so easy to adapt to your own personal tastes let's make some stuffed mushrooms I'm a one pot chef on a baking tray lined with some non-stick baking paper I've got 10 mushrooms just little cut mushrooms and all I've done is I've pulled the stalks off each one and I'm just going to brush each one over with a little bit of olive oil in a mixing bowl I've got about a hundred grams of ricotta cheese now you don't need to use ricotta cheese you could use cream cheese you could use crumble up feta pretty much any cheese you like if you like blue cheese it's really good in this now I'm also adding in about a hundred grams of semi dried tomatoes which I have just chopped up into little chunks I'm adding a little bit of fresh basil which I've just chopped up roughly chopped no need to be overly neat quarter of a cup of some grated cheddar cheese 1 egg and season with some salt and some pepper and just mix that all together until it's nice and smooth that's the filling looking good so let's stuff our mushrooms divide the mixture between the mushrooms but what you want to do is you don't want to be actually just filling them you want to have a little bit of a mound of mixture on top of each so that way it's nice and filled like so and our stuffed mushrooms are ready to go into the oven preheated oven 180 degrees Celsius for about 20 minutes or until the mushrooms are cooked and the top is nice and golden then we'll be ready to eat our stuffed mushrooms have just come out of the oven you can see some of the juices are flowing out of the mushrooms now allow them to cool for a few minutes before we serve them up because we don't want to burn anybody's mails let's have a taste so many flavors those tomatoes because they're marinated in herbs and garlic absolutely gorgeous the basil really comes through you've got that creamy almost salty flavor of the ricotta the burst of cheese from the cheddar cheese from the mushrooms of beautiful and tender YUM well I hope you've enjoyed this recipe check out my other videos at one-pot chef show calm until next time see you later
longtext.label: all

longtext.content: many people these days are afraid of stuffing that's cooked inside of a chicken or other bird there are packaged Stove Top Stuffing mixes on the market but the results are synthetic full of chemicals they generally taste pretty awful here's a recipe for a natural Rich flavorful stuffing that's indistinguishable from the classic sage and mushroom stuffings that used to cook in the cavity of the Sunday bird although this is obviously more work than the packaged mix the result is a million times better I was working on perfecting this recipe at a restaurant in Beverly Hills quite a few years back when uh Chef Wolf Gang Puck stopped by he tasted it and told me don't change a thing yeah I know it made him sound like Arnold Schwarzenegger but that's how he always sounded to me the first step of this is to prepare the bread uh you want a loaf that's fairly dense not like a cake loaf don't use like a Wonder Bread or something like that it has to be like real bread um it can be stale but it really won't make any difference here cuz we're going to bake it anyway so if you've got stale use stale if you all you can get is fresh find use fresh um now you're going to cut this up into cubes now we're going to begin making the uh liquid that goes over the top of this bread I'm going to put in cut up red bell peppers I took the garlic cloves and I just sliced them in off um I'm going to add some dried rosemary to this uh this is one of those instances where I'm actually I don't want the high notes of the herb which is why I'm putting that in now I just want that this background deep richness is all we're going for now um with the paprika and we'll put a little bit of salt we're going to we're going to adjust the seasoning later but is salted all the way through so that you don't end up in the end with bread has no saltiness to it at all in within the stuffing okay there's the olive oil now this gets uh usual stick blender treatment this is the Brad that I cubed up um I cubed it fairly large because that's the way that I like it uh if you Cube it too small in the end what you're going to end up with is is really uh like a soup almost of instead of a like a discernable stuffing so I always want to guard against that personally I I don't like that too squishy of soft um texture in the end I want to be able to to identify and taste the bread um okay so I've scraped out the contents of this and we're going to begin mixing it you just really just got to get your hands in there and do it's the only way make it as even as you can and here it is spread out on a single layer in the baking sheet I've preheated the oven to 150 c as soon as it goes in I'm going to lower the temperature and turn the fan on you can play around with these proportions you know up and down these are the ones I'm comfortable with because I've made it many many times I like this the best 160 180 200 the W this is in the oven also you get plenty of time hopefully got plenty of time to cut up your your vegetables the celery the mushrooms and the onions and cut them into um you know reasonable size chunks like inch bre is still toasting in the oven I'm going to begin cooking the other ingredients when the butter is foamed up going to add the uh onions to it and start counting a Time the temperature here on the stove is on a six from 1 to 10 stir this around a little bit let it go for a few 5 minutes by the clock now I'm going to add the celery and a little bit of salt you have to be careful not to overs salt this but you want to make sure that the celery has some salt in there to break it down the salt will exude moisture from the celery in from the onion but you want to you want to make sure the celery is soft in this you don't want it to have nasty hard chunks in the end so stir it around once in a while a little bit let it keep cooking okay it's now been 8 minutes since I added the cery now I'm going to add the mushrooms and the same routine stir them around one once in a while let them continue to cook it's been just over 13 minutes so far but you can you know after you do this a couple time you can just use your own judgment just look at it this is also the time you want to start picking your Sage leaves off preparing the your shien of these to go in don't want to do it too early because the uh Aroma will evaporate into the air but we're getting pretty the mushrooms have been cooking for about 3 minutes now I'm going to kill the Heat and I'm going to add the dark chicken stock by the way this is what chicken stock that's properly made should look like it should be gelatinous not like the stuff you get in the store okay there's no heat on here but I'm using the residual heat in the pan to to make sure that this melts thoroughly into the um into the mixture here okay it's been 40 minutes now the bread came out of the oven you want to make sure that there's no burn on it at all it's I've used a low temperature for a long time this is very rich and a concentrated flavor but it's no it's absolutely not burnt in any way that's important because if it's burnt it'll make the the overall stuffing bitter I transferred the uh cooked vegetables and chicken stock into Bowl that's all I did and I'm adding uh that chipot of sage and now I'm adding all the breadcrumbs to this more like crutons really um and I'm going to mix this up but I'm not going to add the egg yet I'm going to let this sit and absorb all this liquid I don't want to add the egg because first of all it'll start spoilage and second of all it will actually interfere with the absorption of the the liquid by the bread so we're just going to mix this around and let it stand after you're satisfied that it's mixed as well as you can put some cing film over it let it stand for a while go on after about half an hour we remove the clean film I've got the um one whole egg and the egg yolk this up little first sure it breaks up and I'm also going to put a little fresh ground white pepper on this too remember it's had no pepper added so far okay now we're going to stir this up and get ready to start baking it here take a ceramic baking dish I'm going to put some butter and rub the bottom of it with butter just to make sure it doesn't stick as you got egg and bread in there it's kind of classic for sticking to the pan as it's breaking okay put the mixture in here sure you get everything smooth it out now for the first period of cooking I'm going to cover it with foil this will make sure that the bread doesn't end up drying up and and turning chewy which is something you want to make very sure to avoid cuz nobody likes chewy stuffing okay it's going the oven for the first period it's been 30 minutes now remove the cover and it goes back in for the remaining time this is 10 minutes after it's been in the oven without a cover and I'm going to sprinkle some vermouth on it dry vermouth don't have to do this but it's a nice touch and now it's to go back in the oven and now after the last 10 minutes uh I'm going to do is I'm going to put this cover back on it in order to retain some of that moisture so it doesn't all evaporate out now so we want it want the stuffing to be moist just let it sit like this till it cools down also look for my cocktail book cocktails of the South Pacific and Beyond Advanced Mixology available through Amazon online
longtext.label: all

longtext.content: [Intro music] Assalaamu Alaikum and welcome to Titli's Busy Kitchen with me Titli Nihaan. I'll know that some of you will be thinking about stuffing your bird right now but maybe, recently, things have gone a bit humdrum, a little bit samey and you want a little bit more adventure in your stuffing. Don't despair because in this video I'll show you something that will maybe bring back a little bit of the magic. There's enough here to stuff a 4 kg or 10 pound bird. Here I've got 250 g of breadcrumbs. 500 g of finely chopped mushrooms. I actually used a food processor to chop these. 250 g of spring onions or green onions or scallions. Whatever you want to call them. Here's one I didn't prepare earlier. A 150 g of something like either bacon or I'm using a halal salami. A 125 g of butter. 3 tablespoons of freshly chopped rosemary. Dried rosemary is fine too. 4 crushed cloves of garlic. Begin by melting the butter in a large pan. Once the butter is melted, add in the onions, the bacon or in my case, my salami and the garlic. Sauté gently until the onions become soft. After about 5 minutes or so, gentle sautéing, the onion should be nice and soft. I'll turn off the heat. I'll just season it with a little bit of salt and pepper. Add in all the remaining ingredients: the mushrooms, the breadcrumbs and the rosemary. Give it all a good mix. When everything is nicely mixed, it's ready for use! It's kinda hard to make a bowl of stuffing look attractive but it does taste awesome! So now there's no excuse for the same thing, year in, year out. I do hope that you enjoy good stuffing this year and do join me next time in Titli's Busy Kitchen with me Titli Nihaan. Until next time... Khuda hafiz�
longtext.label: all

longtext.content: - Hey dudes, I'm Hilah and today on Hilah Cooking I'm making spinach stuffed mushrooms. Hidden Valley Ranch asked me to come up with a recipe that would be great for an awards season party and I think these fit the bill because you can make 'em ahead of time, ladies love vegetables and they go really great with champagne and talking about celebrities. (electronic instrumental music) Start out with prepping the mushrooms. I've got some pretty big cremini mushrooms here that I just wiped off with a damp towel to get off all the dusties off and then you just wanna pop the stem out and I find the easiest way to do it it kind of like going around and break this membrane if you need to, sometimes it's not there, but I think fresher mushrooms usually have that little membrane and then just kind of pop it out. And it literally makes a popping sound, so that's cool and then if you're the type of person that makes like your own vegetable stock or chicken stock and stuff, save these mushroom stems, 'cause those go really well in something like that. So I'll show you another one. So once you've got your mushrooms ready to roll, you can push those aside and we'll start mixing up our filling. The base of it is gonna be some cream cheese. Add a little bit of mayonnaise. And I'm gonna add one packet of Hidden Valley salad dressing and seasoning mix. Just get these mixed up together. Okay, so this looks really good. It's all smooth. So we can add the rest of our filling ingredients, so I'm gonna use a little bit of grated cheese. I'm using Monterrey Jack. I think cheddar would be really good too. Some grated carrots. Some finely chopped spinach. Some green onions and some fresh herbs. Today I'm gonna use some dill and parsley, but you could use all dill or all parsley. And then some bread crumbs. You wanna save some to put on the top of the stuffed mushrooms later and I'm gonna add some black pepper. And then just get this all mixed up. Okay, so once you're certain that your mixture is very well combined and there's no streaks of cream cheese or mayonnaise hiding around the bottom, we can stuff the mushrooms. So I'm using a baking tray that I've lined with a little bit of parchment. You don't need to do that, but it makes clean up a little bit easier. So then we can just start filling the mushrooms and I just use a regular spoon and do a teaspoon and a half or two teaspoons, depending on the size of the mushroom. (easy listening instrumental music) Once your mushrooms are all stuffed, you just wanna sprinkle the top of each one with a couple pinches of bread crumbs. Just to make sure you get a nice little toasty brown top and add a little bit of crunch. And if you did wanna make these ahead of time, you could just refrigerate them for up to hour and then bake them whenever you're ready for some hot stuffed mushrooms. So I'm gonna put these in a preheated 400 degree oven and bake 'em for 20 to 25 minutes, until the mushrooms are nice and soft and kind of shrively and the tops are brown and toasty and everything inside is all melty and yummy and gooey. Alright, so 20 minutes later and my house smells amazing and these look gorgeous and I can't wait to eat one. For this recipe, check out hilahcooking.com and for many, many, many more recipes, check out hiddenvalley.com/recipe. Now, let's taste this recipe. They're gonna be hot so beware. Biter beware. Ya'll really should try this. This is one of my favorite stuffed mushroom recipes that I've ever had or even ever created. So thank you so much for watching, thanks for subscribing and I will see ya'll next week. Bye. (electronic instrumental music)
longtext.label: all

longtext.content: when it comes to the holidays I have to say my favorite dish is the stuffing I love that mix of flavors and textures and it makes a great leftover before I became a chef I usually prepared the stuff that came in a box but recently I picked it up and read the ingredient label hydrogenated oil hmm monosodium glutamate preservatives and what's this high fructose corn syrup what's that doing in here so this year I'm gonna skip the box stuff and I'm gonna be going into the kitchen and making my own from scratch come and join me and see how it's done for the foundation in our stuffing I went ahead and toasted my bread cubes now I'm using equal parts whole wheat and white and I've toasted these in a really hot oven so they're super super crispy the reason why I want a crispy crouton is so that when you mix it with all the liquids it doesn't fall apart during baking so those are ready to go and now I want to move on here I have my onion my carrot and my celery all ready to go hot pan over medium heat let's turn that up perfect we're gonna add a little bit of olive oil there we go make sure you coat the pan well and because this is a mushroom stuffing recipe we're gonna start off with our mushrooms so here I have some crimini mushrooms all cut up these are gonna go directly in the pan there we go and now I don't like mushrooms that are super soft and squishy so what I want to do watch how I do this I'm going to coat my mushrooms with the oil just like that in the pan and then I'm going to let them sit and if you do this you actually end up searing them as opposed to steaming them if you have too many mushrooms in the pan the mushrooms will want to release all the liquid and then your mushrooms kind of end up soft and mushy that's not my goal in this recipe you can hear how the mushrooms are squeaking in the pan that's good because it means they're not drowning in their own liquid they're searing perfectly now these are done I'm gonna take them off the heat and add a little sprinkle of salt just like that and a few grinds of pepper now you may wonder why I don't add salt and pepper in the beginning well if you add salt it actually helps your mushroom release liquid and again that's not what I wanted I wanted my mushrooms to sear so now that those are seasoned this is gonna go directly over my bread cubes and look at all that fabulous stuff in the bottom of the pan this is called sook s you see it's a French term and it's all the sugars that have caramelized on the bottom of the pan now that equals great flavor so we don't want to lose this that's why I'm not gonna wash the pan again I'm gonna add a little bit more olive oil there we go coat the pan nicely just swirl it around and now it's time to add the rest of our vegetables so I'm gonna add a little bit of garlic because I like just a little bit of bite and then the rest of our vegetables are going in perfect now all we need to do is saute this similar to the mushrooms until they're starting to turn golden brown I don't want to take them too far because I don't want them to turn into mush while they cook I wish you could smell it in here it smells so good you can see that my vegetables are nicely sauteed I don't want to take them too far but I want to get that brown stuff off the bottom of the pan so I'm gonna deglaze with about a cup of white wine that's gonna help me get all those flavors into the vegetables and give a fabulous flavor to the stuffing if you don't want to use an alcohol like wine go ahead and use chicken stock or even water is totally fine I'm going to let this reduce until almost all the liquid is evaporated and then we're ready to move on see how the liquid is nice and reduced it's time to go ahead and add this to our stuffing mix now before I do it I'm in a season with salt and pepper again because I'm creating layers of flavor there we go just a little bit of pepper stir that around and now this goes on top of our bread cubes so pour that on top so now look gorgeous and see how nice and deglaze the pan got that's perfect that's exactly what we were looking for now comes time for the herbs so to this I'm going to add some oregano because I love the flavor of fresh oregano now this is a mushroom in sage stuffing so we want to add our sage now sage is a really strong herb so you don't want to put too much I'm probably gonna use about 1/4 cup in here there we go now for the final step I've got some chicken broth here you can use vegetable that's totally fine to it I'm going to add a couple of eggs now you don't want to do this if you're gonna stuff your turkey with this stuffing because the eggs may not cook all the way through but if you're gonna bake your stuffing it's just fine I'm using eggs as a binding agent if you want to leave them out you can certainly do that I think think they add a really nice texture I'm also using low-sodium chicken broth because again I want to be able to control the salt and the pepper in my recipes perfect so now this just goes on top of our vegetables there we go just get that nice and mixed in now you can see there's still a little bit of liquid that doesn't get absorbed by the bread don't worry that's going to absorb as it bakes this is gonna go directly into our oiled baking dish I just sprayed it with a little bit of nonstick cooking spray there we go now this is going to go into the oven and you're gonna cook it for 30 minutes with foil on top and that's gonna cook it all the way through and then you're gonna take the foil off and cook it for another 15 minutes so that that top gets nice and brown all right we're ready for the oven Wow I wish you can smell it in here it smells so wonderful our stuffing is still nice and moist but look at that beautiful crisp crust this is something that everybody is going to enjoy and it doesn't come from a box I hope you'll join me in making Whole Foods for the holidays happy and healthy eating you
longtext.label: all

longtext.content: today on us and our living we will be making spring mix and spinach stuffed portobello caps you will need portobello caps Arlit shallot olive oil butter mushrooms sun-dried tomatoes salt and pepper spring mix and baby spinach and mozzarella cheese start by preheating your oven to 350 degrees Fahrenheit while you wait prepare your mushrooms remove the stem and then remove the gills from your portobello caps with a spoon another way to prepare your mushroom is peeling off the outside skin this just makes it a little easier to cut apart after you've cooked it use a basting brush to cook the inside and outside of your mushroom caps with olive oil make sure to coat your pan as well place your mushrooms topside down in your baking dish sprinkle the inside of your mushrooms with garlic and shallots take your mushroom caps in the oven for about 10 minutes while we wait for the mushrooms to bait go ahead and melt your butter in a saute pan once your butter is melted add your garlic and shallots and cook until translucent on medium heat next add your olive oil and cook until the edges of the garlic and shallots begin to brown in our crispy once your garlic and shallots are crispy go ahead and add your mushrooms and sun-dried tomatoes saute until they're sweated adding salt and pepper to taste once your mushroom mixture is cooked go ahead and take some of your spring mix and baby spinach and put it on one side of the pan we're going to cook these until they are wilted add a couple handfuls at a time you don't want to over stuff your pan once your greens are nice and wilted go ahead and take this off heat next take your mushrooms out of the oven be careful they will be very hot stuff your caps with your mushroom and greens mixture you want to align your filling up to the edge of the portobello cap if you overstuff them they will fall apart in the next step you finally top here mushrooms with mozzarella cheese we're using via vegan mozzarella shreds but any mozzarella cheese would work once you're done topping these pop them back into the oven until the cheese has melted while you're waiting you can prepare a bed of baby greens to place them on once they come out once your cheese has melted place on a bed of baby greens we topped ours with vegan mushroom gravy if you'd like to see how we made that check the link in the description below as always thanks for watching like if you liked it and subscribe for more videos

tablespoons of corn the same applies for the kidney beans one small onion finely chopped about one tablespoon of sour cream some sriracha sauce demand depends on how spicy you want the recipe to be 1 clove of garlic a handful of grated mozzarella cheese and finally some chives as decoration first we're going to start off by preparing the mushrooms if your mushroom has a stem just remove it by snapping it off make sure that you don't break your portobello mushroom then take a spoon and remove these hairy bits or yeah I don't know how to call them just scrape them off a bit set them aside we're not going to be wasteful in this recipe so we're going to add this to the filling later there we go something like this so here I have a pan with some olive oil in there now let's put it on a fire and let it get hot once the oil is hot add in your onion and let it fry for a bit once the onion starts looking blazing let's add the mushroom give it a good stir and fry this for about a minute then crushing your garlic make sure not to over fry your garlic otherwise it won't become bitter starting to smell really really nice at this point it's optional to season your mushrooms I'm just going to season them with some and a little bit of salt now let's add in the key beans and the corn and fry that for about three to four minutes to make it a better greener you can sprinkle a little bit of chives in there or you can leave them all as decoration that's all up to you at this point you can turn up the fire now let's add a good tablespoon of sour cream and of course it depends how spicy you want it squeeze a good amount of sriracha sauce on top let's mix everything up and there you go the filling is done take a tray covered with baking paper and place your portobello mushrooms on there then take your filling and put it in the mushrooms there we go top it off with mozzarella cheese there we go now put them into a preheated oven at 200 degrees Celsius for about five to eight minutes and there you go about eight minutes later the mushrooms are done all we have left is to decorate them with some chives and there you go as you can see this one is falling apart a bit because the edges were not as sturdy as this one so if you're making these make sure that your portobello mushrooms have a sturdy edge and they're really firm besides that it's pretty damn good I can't wait
